All our vociferous chums,
who shouted long and loud
about student government
this year, can demonstrate
the stuff they're made of in
the next few days. The
NEWS LETTER is still asking council candidates to publish statements of policy
(or platforms) in its next and following issues. But
we're really getting tired. After all, three years is a
long time to push a project, with discouraging results.
At any rate, we're willing to keep trying and make
our facilities available. We hope our campus cleangovernment Zealots still retain sufficient of their earlier
enthusiasm to support us in making this a worthwhile
undertaking.
And while we're on politics: An active, and, on the
whole, excellent council this year has led many to
lose sight of the real political morass into which we
sink steadily deeper. Any ultimate good coming out
of our student government this year isn't coming because of student interest, but rather despite it! Under
our present system of stooge voting (sans even election
cigars), it's pure luck when we get a decent council.
Luck doesn't hold out forever.
There's nothing wrong with politics! That's the
democratic method for choosing and working governments. But dirty, double-crossing, cheap politics is
not for us, thank you. As we see it, there must be a
method of knowing what a man intends, voting for
him on that basis, and then holding him responsible for
effecting it.
Political parties might offer a solution. A few weeks
back, the NEWS-LETTER ran a pre-vote analysis of the
Council. It could be seen therein that our political
sentiments fall into three categories: Liberal, Conservative, Moderate. This furnishes a good basis for party
platforms.
Under such a set-up, affiliated men could be gauged
by votes, and their party held responsible for them.
It's a simple scheme, but it works. All we need are a
few men who'll start working instead of talking and
times will change.
